name: Moderator Tom
comment info:
Thanks to all the students who responded.   Here are some of the catchy headlines that we received:  “Train Cars Derailed, Is Your Town Next?” by Michael of Elk County Catholic High School in St. Marys, Pennsylvania; “Going Off the Rails: Train Derailments Toxifying America” by Izzy of Andover High School in Massachusetts; "Getting Off Track: Train Derailments Happen More Often Than You Think" by Finn of Eaglecrest High School in Aurora, Colorado; “National Train Derailment Graph Raises More Questions Than Answers” by Katherine Clark of Lexington, Georgia; and "Midwest Becomes Home to Derailment Hot Spots. Can These Catastrophes Be Explained?" by Yohandry and "Off The Rails: 47 Years of Derailed Train Cars" by Joelyna, both from Perth Amboy High School in New Jersey.

 

The next “What’s Going On In This Graph?” will be released by Friday, March 10 with moderation on Wednesday, March 15.  The topic – Words Used.  

Signing off – Sharon Hessney from Boston, who lives near freight lines and should know if hazardous cargo travels on these lines, and Tom Rothery, math teacher from Chandler, Arizona,  who works at Chandler Unified School District.

name: Moderator Tom
comment info:
Thank you, all, for your posts! There are brilliant minds amongst the many of you.
It is true. The right side of the United States map was more-heavily blotted with RED, but notice the concentration of color around certain states and counties. 
What contributes to this representation? Maybe consider when and where railways first originated in the United States, and to further consider the "purposes" for such railways. How have we restored and maintained railways from when they were first created centuries ago?
Further, while the west appears to have fewer derailments, is it due to stronger safety standards or the possibility of having fewer cars or transportation routes? 
Is it possible that states such as Pennsylvania and Ohio actually have a smaller proportion of railroad derailments per route when compared to states in the west? 
Thank you, again, to all who contributed comments to this week's article. In the end, finding a solution to train derailment is a primary concern for the safety of all. You all shared numerous thoughts that may help point a direction to finding resolutions to such tragic developments.

name: Dr Jeff
comment info: We do indeed need to worry about train derailments especially for ones carrying potentially toxic chemicals.  The case in point is the recent derailment in Palestine, Ohio.  In a study of air by the Carnegie Mellon’s Wilton E. Scott Institute for Energy around the Palestine train derailment, one of the chemicals detected was acrolein (a lung irritate and a known carcinogen).  It was found to be several times higher than in the air than the levels in downtown Pittsburgh on the same day.  Acorlein is also a product of automobile exhaust and has long been considered a potential health hazard in traffic tunnels.  The acorlein half-time (the time for half of it to decay) is on the order of less than a day, but if the input rates exceeds this then it will build up in air.  Wind may help dissipate acorlein but they could simple transfer the problem to a different place.  Acorlein air measurements should be carried out in a routine way both at further derailment site and the surrounding area.
